Nevertheless, #ShePersisted. She set up a special performance. Desi proves his comedy chops, and wins the part.

‘I Love Lucy’ becomes the most-watched show in America four years in a row, beaming a funny, loving, interracial marriage into tens of millions of households. pic.twitter.com/OCmuTU2qAw

Ms. Ball goes to @CBS and insists that Desi Arnaz, her husband—and a Cuban American—be cast as her husband in the show.

The studio refuses.

Here's another story about #MediaDiversity.

It’s 1950, over 90% of Americans approve of laws banning interracial marriage, and Lucille Ball is asked by CBS to star in a new comedy—the show that would soon become "I Love Lucy."  https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1172203130068570112 … pic.twitter.com/BVJR37FOhT

This is an issue that has come up repeatedly in our discussions around #MediaDiversity, and one reason why I felt that our new congressional resolution was necessary to bring light to the issues faced across the American media landscape. https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1172098710584606720 …

This is an important point, and one often overlooked in the struggle for #MediaDiversity in America. Even when organizations make an effort to do the right thing, those efforts are too often the victim of the business climate.

This is especially hard for local, independent media https://twitter.com/AsteadWesley/status/1171860183057928192 …

If we believe that “we hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men (and women) are created equal," then we should all know that we are better, stronger, more complete, when we celebrate and utilize the diversity among us.

#MediaDiversity has a key role to play. https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1172203162159108097 …

America is increasingly multicultural and multiethnic. But news and entertainment doesn’t always reflect that reality.

Most important of all, we need recognition of minority groups not merely as tokenized individuals, but as fundamental building blocks of America.

Even as America has become more diverse, we have seen difficulties with #MediaDiversity. Rural, local, community, and minority outlets—and even major metropolitan papers—have been bought up and dismantled, or simply could not survive.

These are vital voices for our communities. https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1172098710584606720 …
Today we celebrate @maejemison's historic accomplishments as the first black woman in space.  https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1172203150448766977 … pic.twitter.com/gQhR7SiV6z

That's why I'm grateful to @RepJenniffer, @marcorubio, @SenJackyRosen, and our 66 cosponsors for their support on our new resolution to encourage diversity in American media. Congress should be loud and clear: diversity matters, and we have the power to speak up in its defense.

The point is this: the moment when a young child first sees a cultural icon who looks like them can be the moment that changes everything.

As we work towards a more optimistic, united future, it's is more important than ever that ALL children have that chance.

While Dr. Jemison was training to be an astronaut, she tracked down Ms. Nichols at a Star Trek convention in #Orlando, and since then they've worked together to promote #science, #STEM, and #space, and to open doors of opportunity for children across America. pic.twitter.com/l5zqvVpsSN

27 years ago today, Dr. Mae Carol Jemison became the first black woman to travel in space, after an accomplished career as a biomedical engineer.

Dr. Jemison had been inspired by Sally Ride, the first American woman in space—and by watching Nichelle Nichols on Star Trek. pic.twitter.com/f0qQW2WfTI

Nichols not only stuck with the show, she leveraged the show's success and her iconic role to recruit women of color to be @NASA astronauts, touring the country to find promising candidates. pic.twitter.com/JRgwN2LMBZ

One child watching was @WhoopiGoldberg, who at nine years old ran through the house shouting “come quick, there's a black lady on television and she ain't no maid!” “I knew right then and there,” Goldberg said, that “I could be anything I wanted to be.” pic.twitter.com/SyVsP7Vs9a

Dr. King told her how valuable, how vital it was that for once, on television, black Americans were being seen as intelligent, valued, beautiful people who could go into space or do anything else. He told her, “we look on that screen and we know where we’re going.”

Then, at a @NAACP fundraiser, she heard there was a Trek fan, and turned around to see Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. 

She told Dr. King that she wanted to leave the show and join the marches for civil rights, and to her shock, Dr. King told her…you can’t.

Ms. Nichols has spoken in interviews about the prejudice she faced at the time—even being turned away from the studio’s entrance because the guards thought she didn’t belong there. At the end of the first season, she decided to leave.

Here's a story about why #MediaDiversity is so important:

In 1966, @StarTrek debuted. Though America was struggling with civil rights, @NichelleIsUhura was cast as an officer on the bridge of the starship. It was one of the first major primetime roles for a black actress.  https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1172098710584606720 … pic.twitter.com/xuijVbMjqd

Now, today, September 12, 2019, @HouseJudiciary are expanding our power to investigate, to collect and catalogue the evidence, and to move towards a final decision around articles of impeachment.

I believe that those articles are not only warrented, they are required.

On August 7, 2019, we filed suit to enforce our subpoena for Mr. McGahn. There again, we told the court that we require his testimony in order to help decide whether to recommend articles of impeachment.

On July 26, 2019, we asked a federal court for access to grand jury information, and we told the court that it falls to this Committee to ‘exercise . . . a constitutional power of the utmost gravity—approval of articles of impeachment.’

On June 11, 2019, the House approved H. Res. 430, authorizing this Committee to enforce its subpoenas in court. The Committee report stated explicitly that our work includes whether to approve articles of impeachment with respect to the President.

On May 8, 2019, we recommended that the House hold Attorney General Barr in contempt. As part of that recommendation, the Committee was clear that our work ‘includes whether to approve articles of impeachment with respect to the President.’

On March 4, 2019, we sought information from many sources related to ‘alleged obstruction of justice, public corruption, and other abuses of power by President Trump.’ This is the same behavior which formed the basis of the impeachments of Presidents Nixon and Clinton.

If anyone is confused about @HouseJudiciary’s intentions, let there be no more doubt.

Today’s resolution, like our previous actions, states explicitly that our purpose is to consider impeaching President Trump—an action I support.
